commentBody: I thought this one was going to be a massive fail, but then it was solved. I didn't figure out what kind of "sitting" was being done in 57D until after I had finished. And I didn't notice the two ICEs until I read the notes. This was definitely a Saturday for me.

Serious question:  is there a reason why I should have known that the letter crossing PSILOC_BIN and Z_NGA is a Y?  It could have been A, E, I, O, U, or Y as far as I can tell.  Since Z_NGA is a made-up word, you could even argue that it could have been H, K, or T.

Re: 1A: Dada was not a style but a movement, a rebellion against the political and economic system that had produced colonialism, industrial exploitation of workers and consumers, and destructive wars. An artistic style is a set of design criteria that can be reduced to a set of descriptive or prescriptive rules. Dada was by its very nature a rejection of all rules, and those who rejected it did so because of its anarchistic nature.

I don‚Äôt know if it was just me, but this puzzle seemed to have ATON of fairly esoteric general knowledge questions.  I‚Äôm sure there will be quite a few complaints.  I actually looked up ELLIE Bamber, the first time I‚Äôve had to resort to Google in quite some time, and after that it did come together.  Not my favorite puzzle, although I did learn some things.

Wow, how the d_vil did I finish this one.  That was hard.  I knew hardly anything in the puzzle.

I guess this means it was constructed well and I made some decent guesses.  Yikes.  Still a tough and scary one for me.  As we've learned, the really long answers are often surprisingly accepting hunch fodder.

And yet in the end it didn't take all that long.  Strange.

Really not looking forward to seeing others say how easy it was.  ;)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Lovely to see Leonora Carrington, the Lancashire-born but very much Mexican painter, in the crossword. Other than that I didn't really enjoy anything about it.

Wow, the Unknown Names: LEONORA, ELLIE, DEVA, and ANTOINETTE as a first name (Marie Antoinette I have heard of).  As others have said, it seemed really tough but I was surprised to finish in under 20 minutes which is not bad for a Saturday.

Great grid spanners!   And I loved the DVD nestled beside the CD CASES up top.
At least I‚Äôm confident I googled less in solving this than the author did in creating it lol

What a brilliant piece of work this puzzle is.   Easy fills made opaque by witty cluing, with so many AHAH moments I was laughing by the time I finished it.

I started by just dropping in wild some stabs at what I thought might work, like SAMOVAR and DONTMOVEAMUSCLE and they were almost always right, which helped a lot with crosses. By the time I got to "Cream alternative," I was ready for her.

I'll admit I needed a bit of fill help‚ÄîI knew my husband was likely to know at least one, because he's an encyclopedia of off-the-beaten path words (at least my path): PSILOCYBIN; I had to confirm a couple of spellings and find at least one actress. Recently, I had read an article about Leonora Carrington, and there she was! Talk about MIINDMELDS!

Katie Hoody, you are a genius.  More puzzles, please!

Not knowing the grandmother, I tried "Antoinetto", which gave "moan" as excellent, bad, or average.  Excellent and bad fit well (though a little spicy for the NYT), and average could as a stretch (for example, a Steeler fan could moan that his team is always average, never excellent).
That south west corner took me too long trying to work out how to get the Arizona Wildcats to fit in to 46 across.
I came of age in the 70's...psilocybin was definitely a familiar word to college students across the nation.

Wasn't sure about all the vowels for PSILOCYBIN, especially when crossed with ZYNGA, which I could only get from crossings. TMAN and GMAN both seemed appropriate there. But in the end, it was brute forcing the WILDE/DEVA crossing that got me the Gold Star. Of course I've heard of Oscar Wilde, but didn't connect him to that poem.

Fun fact. I went to DRAGONCON at least once about 15 years, so that was a gimme. I enjoyed the intimate atmosphere far more than SDCC, which has more just become a movie trailer forum. More interesting panels in Atlanta than San Diego, too.

37 minutes
I really got a kick out of this one. Good cluing, and I had to go through four spellings of psilo‚Äîpsylo‚Äîthe mushroom thing.
Good one!

ICE PALACE: that must be the place where the ICE RAIN happens?

CONTROLLED CHAOS: better than the other kind?

PSILOCYBIN: a gimme, though not a user. 

Think this grid would make a good themed puzzle involving dominoes, bacilli, or boxcars.
Psilocybin and Leonora Carrington, far out

i had luTES for KITES. Plenty of other natick crosses for me include; WILDE/DEVA, SAMOVAR/RAISA, LEONORA/RENO. It was a brutal puzzle to solve but i really enjoyed getting the long ones, which were surprisingly quite attainable with some perseverance!

Enjoyable, but I was eventually done in by KSU and KITES. I had LUTES initially, which fixated me on stringed instruments, and had the weird effect of making me miss KITES even when I went through the alphabet. The K of KSU I could only guess, and after 5 minutes of flyspecking I lost patience and clicked Check Puzzle.

Another delightful
Saturday puzzle that played out like all my favorite Saturday puzzles ‚Äî seemingly impenetrable, at first, but yielding to perseverance. Not a fan of so many proper names, though ‚Äî they proved the hardest part of this one ‚Äî but was able to suss out what I needed to from the crossings. 

Well done, Katie. Mom would definitely have kept this in a box of memorabilia. I‚Äôm sure she‚Äôd also have put a completed puzzle up on the fridge ‚Äî proud of your construction, and of her completing it.
All that and the great Muddy Waters too!

MINDMELDS, PSILOCYBIN, and DRAGONCON

Loved it.  My inner nerd was happy with these.

I started out with DADA and DECO without a hitch, but as the solve progressed, I felt like I was taking a general knowledge test and unabashedly decided it would be an open book one. After I plugged in some unknowns, I was off to the races and able to enjoy the puzzle. There was much to learn and I can only hope I'll remember an ounce of it. Very instructive puzzle! And the rest, spanners and misdirects, were great fun. For today's musical accompaniment, I offer a Beatles tune, the chorus of which includes "Jai Guru DEVA Om" ‚Äì https://youtu.be/90M60PzmxEE?si=gR_hPHyjdRA-3HeX Thank you, Ms. Hoody, for a top-notch puzzle and the beautiful words about your mom. Your tribute to her with DAISIES in the grid is quite touching. No doubt she'd be very proud!

I really enjoyed this puzzle, and it was a satisfying solve with some clever cluing, especially 45D and 62A. I knew how to SAY the answer to 30D but have never actually spelled it out. Fortunately was able to channel Mr. Spock (or was it the Vulcan mind probe) for the answer to 23 A. Thanks to Ms. Hoody for a challenging and fun end to Friday evening.
Fun fact: "Cut the blue wire" cones from Richard Lester's movie "Juggernaut." I'm very fond of this one. He also directed the Beatles movie "Help!"

Maybe it‚Äôs just been a difficult week, but like others I felt there was a much higher share of general knowledge questions than usual in this puzzle. Yes, I was able to figure out the long crosses, and there were a few clever clues - but overall, I found it a joyless slog.

Usually when I successfully gold star a Saturday, I‚Äôm very proud of myself until I read the comments saying how easy it was and the quality of puzzles have diminished to cater to the devolution of todays youth (blah blah blah). But not today! Guess playing Words With Friends for the past 15 years paid off finally!

Wow. I have no idea how I completed this with no lookups. I knew RAISA but nothing else so the rest was a series of total guesses that eventually coalesced into making sense. In other words, my favorite kind of Saturday puzzle! A workout!

Lost my streak.  There were just too many squares that I couldn't come up with the right vowel.  I looked all over and finally decided I didn't deserve the star and did a puzzle reveal.

I had GMeN rather than GMAN.  Never notice that ITeL wasn't right.

Not my night.

This went beyond hard and tipped into mean. 14 proper nouns, many of them obscure (although oddly I got ZYNGA without much trouble). I decided early on I wasn‚Äôt bothering with the gold star. One of the least enjoyable solves I can remember.

Two other things:

- I‚Äôve said this before but no one calls Kansas State University KSU. It‚Äôs referred to as K-State.
- As a native Floridian and day one Tampa Bay Lightning fan, I can tell you their arena was originally named the Ice Palace, and it was built first. Cluing that entry with a Russian building instead was‚Ä¶ a choice.
What does ‚Äúshow competitive features‚Äù do in the settings? I have toggles it on and off a few times and never noticed a change. I can‚Äôt find an explanation anywhere. Thanks.

I haven‚Äôt had this much difficulty since I started doing the NYT crossword, over 2 years ago. There were simply too many names and words that I didn‚Äôt know and clues I couldn‚Äôt hammer out, even with some lookups. And even some things I thought I knew (Arizona Wildcats), I didn‚Äôt. Oh, well. It‚Äôs good to be humbled.
An enjoyable Saturday puzzle - finished it in my average (MEAN) time. I don‚Äôt understand the ‚ÄúRoyal adversary‚Äù clue though. TWIN?
No lookups, but man did I have to work for it. One of the toughest Saturdays in recent memory!

This was a challenging and enjoyable puzzle.

I did like "way-out fun" and "angled for attention." 
It was also nice to see samovar again.  It's been a while.

Have a wonderful, solution-filled weekend and may the "Madness of March" just be on the basketball courts.

This was such a great puzzle and an extremely enjoyable solve! I struggled a little at first, but after I got going, everything fell into place in such a pleasant way and in less than half of my Saturday average. 

The top middle section was the hardest for me, but once I managed to find 21A rolling around in my brain, I got the poet and that cracked the problematic nook.

Huzzah, what an excellent start to a sunny day!

Anyone else think that US universities should be able to come up with unique nicknames for their sports teams, especially, like, when they're in a conference comprising only 12 teams?

I mean, 2x Cougars + 2x Wildcats? Come on people, there are loads of animals to choose from... Or maybe even go for non-animal nicknames cause you're not in high-school any more!

I just recently watched the Wordplay documentary on YouTube and felt extra dumb solving this puzzle after getting totally stumped on the bottom half about 13 minutes in‚Ä¶.  Took a break,  came back and finished well under my Saturday average time but no where close to the phenoms in the documentary.  Oh well, not planning a trip to Connecticut anyway‚Ä¶

I really enjoyed this puzzle. Something about it was just right for me difficulty-wise.

I just kept circling and circling and eventually the top opened up for me but it took me longer than usual to feel like I was actually getting somewhere.

Yes. Ohgod, yes. This was the Saturday puzzle I needed. 

KSU, thy name nearly became my puzzle Waterloo today.

I enjoyed what little of this puzzle I was not forced to reveal by not being smart and informed enough ü§£

I think I knew one of the names in this grid ü§™. Being well educated and reasonably well read in Poland doesn't really translate well into American culture, at all. It's funny how lost I feel in these puzzles, sometimes, but of course it's on me. Especially on Saturday I don't mind being completely destroyed by a crossword.

Really tough one for me. Had to look up some stuff and even after that it was a lot pondering and working the crosses. More than a couple of completely unfamiliar (to me) answers. At least relieved to see that for once I'm not entirely alone in that. A couple of interesting puzzle finds today, both inspired by Muddy Waters. Here's one: A Monday from August 12, 1996 by Janet R. Bender. Four theme answers in that one: MUDDYWATERS RUSTYNAILS GREASYSPOON DIRTYHARRY Thought that was cute. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/12/1996&g=11&d=D I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ....

Fun puzzle! I had ATON of unknowns for a long time, and several guesses that turned out to be right. The one that really delighted me was spelling PSILOCYBIN correctly the first time! Woo hoo! Katie Hoody's dedication to her mom was lovely. Our parents influence us (positively if we're lucky) long after they are gone..
Thanks for the wonderful puzzle. I hope the 46 down and across connection is a little Kansas easter egg!
Had to lookup too many clues.

Had almost nothing after the first pass, and then it slowly came together. Finished in 44:44, which is not something to brag about, but it does look neat!

For a long time, I didn't notice the first accent on b√©b√©, and was looking for a Spanish word. Which inspired to following Ode to Crosswords, hope you enjoy :)


Tricky clues and lots of punning,
from constructors all too cunning
Keep the scary world at bay
with your puzzle of the day

Yes, you'll have to know some sports
(and the really boring sorts)
US states and Asian mountains,
music bands and Trevi fountains.

Learn some Spanish, learn some French
know that reek's the same as stench
Memorize some German stuff,
as for Russian, nyet's enough

Know your Shakespeare, know your Plath,
some biology and math
Have an atlas at the ready,
golden stars are pretty heady

Run the alphabet when stuck,
or write in ink and show your pluck
Google things and don't feel bad
it's your game, as someone said

This is exactly what I hope for in a Saturday morning puzzle.  Lots of unknowns that have to be teased out, ambiguous clues, and overall great fill.  

Thanks, Katie, I needed that.
I kept trying to fit UA (Arizona) into three spaces for the Wildcats answer. Guess that was due to my locale. And why would one conference have two Wildcat teams? Sports - so mysterious.
What a perfect Saturday morning puzzle

CD cases do not protect "software" (they protect the medium before it is installed as software). Bad clue -- anachronistic and just plain incorrect. BTW If you are still buying software on CD's (if that's even possible), then you are probably due for a prostate check.

Today was quite a challenge! Thank you, Katie.

The SW corner proved to be a bear, mainly because I know little to nothing about sports teams. But LSU seem to fit, which gave me LUTES -which come with strings. But something seemed amiss and I couldn‚Äôt imagine a Louisiana team having ‚Äúwildcat‚Äù  as its mascot. I‚Äôm thinking more like pelicans or gators.
So- KSU was a rare ‚Äúlookup‚Äù. 
And the ‚Äúy‚Äù connecting PSILOCYBIN and ZYNGA was, alas, a true Natick for me. Way over my average time, but a lot of fun anyway.
I found this puzzle to be nearly impossible.  Congrats to those who found it doable.

What a gorgeous grid design, that palette of black squares.  It has enough play in it to not be boring, and yet it‚Äôs not so random as to be un-noticeable. Pairs of blocks, half horizontal and half vertical, truly, a CONTROLLED CHAOS, and I wonder if that answer amidst this design is no accident.

This was a faith solve for me, where I kept running into no-knows, but kept telling myself that the constructor and NYT team put it together fairly, and that if I stuck with it, there would be a happy ending.

It turned out to be a Jenga solve, where the puzzle stood firm for a period, firmly fighting me even as I chipped away plugging answers in.  Then, suddenly, it fell in a massive heap after I filled one of the spanners.  Bam!  Bam!  Bam!  A thrilling maxi-splat.  

Along the way, shimmering beauty in those four spanners, the frisson of pop (five NYT debuts, four once-befores, and three twice-befores), and lovely cluing, including the sing-song [Snicker bit] for HEH, and the uber-misdirecting [Royal adversary] for TWIN. 

A splendid Saturday.  Thank you so much for this, Katie, and may there be more to come!

Glorious!

Answers that were so much fun
I smiled typing them in!

CONTROLLED CHAOS?
MINDMELD?
PSILOCYBIN?
TICKING TIME BOMB?
ICE PALACE?

Felt like I was a toddler in a ball pit.
But the balls were words.
And there weren‚Äôt germs everywhere.
And‚Ä¶never mind.

It was just super-duper fun.


Hope something lovely happens today
for each and every one of you!

No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button.

Strange... Twice today I've read a comment with quite a few replies and when I clicked on View All Replies, rather than showing me the rest of the replies the original comment and its replies disappeared! Has anyone else had this happen?

A week of wonderful puzzles reached a crescendo today! CONTROLLED CHAOS describes this puzzle well. 

After an initial foray, I was in unknown territory, mostly. Lots of trivia, misdirects and obscure stuff. The four entries that span this puzzle were my lifelines.

My knowledge of art history and history came in handy today. I filled in the NW immediately, and that helped me a lot. I was happy to see LEONORA Carrington make her debut. I find her  to be one of the most appealing Surrealists. She painted an eerie yet beautiful world that I love getting lost in.

Thanks Katie! Until next time!

After a pretty bleak initial pass through the Acrosses, where I felt certain only of RAISA and NENE, the Downs provided a few more answers (Hi, Oscar!) and the puzzle started to open up. Not so painful after all.
No complaints.  Thanks, Katie.
OK this was a great one. How do I know? Because when I finished it, I was impressed with myself!

Odd solve for me, in that I got all the longer entries filled before I was half done.
Laugh at me (I did) - I started out with DECO and DADA reversed. Fortunately I knew ETON blue. 
Being a sports fan always helps.
Last square was changing an i to Y in PSILOCYBIN - I knew there was a Y in there somewhere, and ZYNGA was a complete unknown. (Like a rolling stone....I can't help it.)

Best puzzle in a long, long time.  Was genuinely worried for most of it.  With all of the conference movement recently I didn‚Äôt think twice about the KEN wildcats, but when i was hopelessly stuck the big 12 part of that clue finally clicked, which got me to muscle, then the whole answer, then controlled chaos, then it was just some mop-up.  Bravo!

Wonderful Saturday puzzle, as measured especially by what ensued after I finished it. My last input was the cross of DEVA and WILDE, and it made me recall the poignancy I felt after watching the movie "Wilde", and remembering making a connection between his imprisonment and the images of the treadmill in the prison depicted in Downton Abbey.

I thought this wasn't impossible and mostly an appropriate difficulty, but by the time I got to the SW, I had to give up and look some things up. KITES was a really rough crossing:

* Lots of things have strings
* If you didn't know the sports team (or, like me, had the misleading idea of "Arizona Wildcats"), half the letters of the alphabet could substitute for K
* The abbreviation could be many different letters, with "PC" having multiple meanings also
* If you didn't know the British actress, it could reasonably be ELLIE or aLLIE (or oLLIE?)
* The herbarium item seemed like SEEDS but could maybe also be rEEDS, with 46D being a collective noun or weird plural

Although Raisa came to me straight away, I hadn't thought about her in a while.

Different time, different world.

Nice puzzle.

I enjoyed this rugged Saturday puzzle, but it beat me. I somehow guessed right at all that ZYNGA stuff, but I was doing so much politically-correct muttering under my breath about how in the world ‚Äúums‚Äù could politically or computerly be considered discourse (cuz obviously, LSU and lutes). So, I finally went back to re-doubting GMAN, the spelling of psilocybin, the alphabet soup of word-game owners‚Ä¶ things went bad from there for a long time. Never doubt yourself, especially when you‚Äôre wrong. Finally Googled my way into the bowels of US college football, and got the cheat. 

On a positive note, just last night I solved the May 27, 2005 puzzle, which had ICEPALACE, so that helped. With one clue.
Maybe I‚Äôm just being dense, but I get how mean can mean average or bad, but can someone explain how mean can mean excellent?  Thanks.

Hi. I'm not getting KID from the clue 'you might sit for one'. Can anyone enlighten me please?

Great puzzle and took longer than usual.
A real Saturday puzzle. I got most of the long answers from just a few letters, but struggled with other clues..just right for the day
Very difficult, very highbrow puzzle, at least in the fill. At first I thought this was a streak killer, but again, not giving up saw me through. This was a true Saturday satisfier.

Seemed an excellent Saturday puzzle to me. Took me 45 minutes, but solved it unaided. 

There were a lot of proper nouns here, and I only knew a few of them. Still, the puzzle seemed very fair, and I was able to resolve the many unknowns using crosses and commonsense.

A lot of clever clues in this one. "Links in a certain chain" for DAISIES and "Snicker bit" for HEH were two of my favorites. 

Knowing baseball got me TWIN for "Royal adversary", but RENO for the "The Aces of Triple-A baseball" only came one letter at a time. LIked seeing ELLIE and ESSIE, though I knew neither of the actresses.

Ending the puzzle at 65A with "Bird whose diet includes berries that grow on lava" for NENE seemed a bit ridiculous. At that point, "Hawaiian goose" would be have served.

Really enjoyed this one, all in all. Quite the MEAN feat.
14 trivia clues. No.
Wow! What a tough and interesting Saturday. Finishing it has made my day! Rest of the day should be no sweat.

AUGH. The SW corner destroyed my streak. I refused to let go of "lutes" at 46D and ended up hitting Reveal. I'm going to need the editorial team to stop publishing such difficult puzzles when I am super sleepy.

ON A POSITIVE NOTE, I did enjoy the rest of the puzzle! The grid itself is a joy to look at, like some fancy stitching. It also had fantastic fill, from SAMOVAR to TICKING TIME BOMB to MIND MELDS. I am very impressed with myself for spelling PSILOCYBIN right on my first attempt. Praise me.

For those wondering about the frequency of certain team names in NCAA sports:

In the NCAA Women's Basketball tournament, the UK Wildcats will play the KSU (K-State) Wildcats in the second round, in Lexington, KY, tomorrow, each team having won their opening games yesterday.
The ticking time bomb of maze/zynga exploded on me, but on a positive note, the rest made me smile a ton.  Great Saturday puzzle, Katie!

OK  I solved it without lookups except for the spelling of psilocybin - had Zenga not Zynga - did not know this company . It was solvable but felt like there was a ton of esoterica in this one . Liked the punniness but could have done without so many proper names - or at least some easier clues, like nail polish brand for ESSIE . 
Will keep plugging away !

So far, this puzzle is completely frustrating. The clues refer to names / events / people not in my wheelhouse. I would have to look up every second word to complete it. May leave it and work on some older puzzles. Arrgh!

Oh well, the Thursday and Friday puzzles were delightful.
Perfection all around: Grid, fill, clues, column and constructor's notes.  Very well done.  Thanks.

Sooo hard for me! 
Explain HEH please?
That one took a while but was worth every minute.

I needed help but I enjoyed this puzzle

It was one of those puzzles where my wild guesses turned out correct

I guess we do think alike

Late puzzle find. This was just rather surprising to me. A Tuesday from February 27, 1990 by Richard Silvestri. Three 15 letter theme answers in that one - all of them quite familiar pairings, and... each of them making their first and only appearance. Just can't understand why, at 15 letters, they never showed up in any other puzzles. Here they are: DASHERANDDANCER SLEEPYANDSNEEZY ATHOSANDPORTHOS Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=2/27/1990&g=39&d=A ...
I‚Äôm sure I will feel dumb when I hear it, but why does ‚ÄúRoyal adversary‚Äù solve to TWIN?
Your mom would have been over the moon. Great puzzle. Thank you.

Good puzzle! Very chewy. I went all the way around on it last night and was not coming up with much...I thought well, this might be one to solve with the puzzle check on, so I can still have fun...slept on it, came back in the morning; voila! a few more fill-ins, and on each pass, it just came together a little bit more. Crosses helped me guess most of the trivia I didn't know, and when I was still stuck in the SW corner, I came here and got some help with KITES; thank you! KSU, not ASU. 

Here's one I was sure of that was wrong: NICE, for something that can mean excellent, okay, or bad, depending on the context. I had first filled in WHOA, and that was clearly wrong. Then I thought of NICE and was so pleased with myself! Ha. It took a long time to give that up. üòú
Couldn't get it til I finally figured how to spell psilocybin.

Super tough for me--the dreaded "almost" popup generated three Google lookups: ELLIE, ESSIE, and KSU. That last one was even difficult to research, with all the teams claiming Wildcat (and me trying to avoid Big 12, which I figured would just get me a lot of those crossword-answers-for-pay results). In flyspecking, double-checked the mushroom spelling, and  the game company name. Held on to IOS too long, figuring (foolishly) that SoILE might be some kind of toast in another language (but duh, no language indicator in the clue! Get with it, David!). Ultimately fair, but somehow wasn't on my wavelength in the small stuff. The spanner and long entries were marvelous.
Conservatively, I counted 25 clues that were not wordplay but instead trivia. Seems pretty high. The tone started immediately with both 1-Across and 1-Down.
So many mini themes! Raisa crossing with samovar and ice palace, mind melds and psilocybin, dada and deco, Wilde, ode, and I Too, and more! What a treat.

This is the hardest puzzle I‚Äôve done in a while. Actually I gave up. I couldn‚Äôt crack the SW. I just couldn‚Äôt give up swish (cry before a shot) for SMILE. ShEDS for SEEDS was at least a real word.  Like I sad. I just couldn‚Äôt give up swish. 

That said. I thought the puzzle was a little too heavy on proper nouns.  But now realizing the intricacy of the grid design. (Not sure why I didn‚Äôt notice it before).  I think I would have been much for forgiving about anything, even a bunch of trash  fill, given the ‚Äòuniqueness?‚Äô Of this grid design. 

I like Saturdays that humble me. The joy is in the struggle.
Fantastic! Top to bottom the best puzzle I‚Äôve seen in a long while. Such a fun, challenging solve. The past and the present colliding on so many levels. Really nice work. Thank you!

Tricky, tricky, tricky!  
Except when it wasn't.
I still do not get 15A  "Royal adversary"= TWIN.
Having a hard time associating Art DECO with Cubism.
And for a while I had MATCh for "fix (up)"--as in helping out that bachelor friend, but it turned out to be just same old repair PATCH.
Actually enjoyed this ...
TICKING TIME BOMB... The Cleveland (baseball) team had a player who was portrayed in a magazine article...titled TICK...TICK...TICK.  Can't remember his name now.  I'm sure someone else will!
Pretty day today!  Making labels for the two quilts now!  Home stretch!

This is beyond unbalanced and not fun. Make it solvable by actually challenging the solvers instead of centering the entire grid on whether or not you know a bunch of random googled trivia.
20+ random proper nouns, foreign terms, and some of the driest riddles I've ever seen in a crossword. Several unfriendly crosses. The long quote fill-ins were fine.
30D/45D/53A is just plain inexcusable.
The Raisa-samovar-psilocybin combination was a bit much.
A good ol‚Äô Saturday challenge is one thing - a slog through proper noun after proper noun, when you can practically feel the strain of the constructor‚Äôs contortions, is quite another.

Oh, I remembered all those annoying Facebook requests for ZYNGA games. No, I don't want to join your Mafia, or your Pirate Crew, or help on your farm. I didn't know that they also came out with Words with Friends. (I didn't play that either.) ESSIE and ELLIE were MEAN to me, but SAMOVAR more than made up for it, as it's one of my favorite words.

Really enjoyed this one. I thought the obscure trivia was pretty much all gettable via crosses. I also have never heard of ELLIE Bamber or ESSIE Davis or LEONORA Carrington, but they were easy enough to figure out once some crosses fell into place. 

#MakeSaturdaysHardAgain

Thanks to the Dennis Hopper line in Speed, I always associate WildCats with Arizona, which made the lower left hand corner quite the game time stretcher.   One of these days I will start following sports!
I really had to just work the crosses and push through it. Definitely had a couple of look ups on people's names and Zynga.  Finished in 40 something.

so....

We have this strange world today.

In the final years of high school our math teacher was changed - the lady who made my life living hell in year one caused grief to others, too, and many parents asked for her to be substituted. In high school in Poland we have what we call profil, a profile, much like your major in college. @Andrzej Psilocybin mushrooms were pretty popular during my misspent youth. I'm a baby boomer, like a lot of people here, and shrooms ascended during the tune in, turn on, drop out 60s and 70s. Little before my time, but not my siblings' time.

@Nora I suppose drugs have had a somewhat different history over here than in the US. Before 1989 and the advent of democracy and market economy, nobody ever talked about drugs, at all. The official propaganda was: "Everything is perfect! If something appears to not be perfect, it's rot from the West and not our fault!". In the early 90s I was a teen at school, and we had all those talks you must have had over in the US too: "Drugs, cigarettes and alcohol are bad, m'kay?" There was this quite famous poster https://pagowski.pl/pl/p/PAPIEROSY-SA-DO-DUPY/102 about cigarettes, and there must have been ones about drugs, too, and I just don't recall them. There was low-key talk at my high school in the second half of the 90s about drug use, and one of my classmates was supposed to be a drug dealer, but none of it ever interested me and nobody bothered me about it. The press ran shocking articles about heroin addiction, but it was not like any of it was really visible daily in Warsaw. At uni at the turn of the 90s and 00s, I heard about some people taking drugs to help them study, but that's about it. There was no marijuana culture, for example. I was quite boring, I didn't go to parties etc., so I may have missed something, but "something" did not seek me out. These days things are different, maybe, but since I don't have children, I'm not up-to-date on much of what makes current Polish culture and counter-culture. My wife and I often smell weed on our dog walks, though.

Also, Polish law outlaws all drugs. Even possession of minor amounts of marijuana may be considered a crime (I say "may" because prosecutors have an option to not pursue criminal liability when they are sure the drugs were for personal use only, and there was a minute amount of them).

People tried to circumvent that some 15 years ago - thousands of shops with "dopalacze" ("boosters") opened, trading in addictive and stimulating substances not recognized by Polish law as drugs. The thing was, for a drug to be banned, it had to be officially recognized by the government as a drug. The procedure to do that took a long time. So whenever something new appeared on the market, it was unregulated, by definition. Soon enough the law was amended, and the "booster" shops were no more.

At present Polish police is severely understaffed (many people left the force during the democractic backsliding of 2015-2023, because they didn't want to beat up protesters or track down women having abortions, and given the police's bad press, nobody signed up to join anymore; democracy has been restored, but the police's problems persist), so they can't be bothered chasing around teens smoking weed, which is probably why we smell it in our neighborhood in the evenings and at night, and occasionally during the day, too.

IMs was indeed ubiquitous for any service or program that let users instantly message another. DMs came about from social platforms where content was posted for everyone to see...a *Direct Message* then only goes to a specific user, not to everyone. 

In common usage, people will say "slid into my/her/his DMs" to indicate starting a personal conversation. ... "She posted a really enticing picture on Insta, so I slid into her DMs to see if I could get something going with her." 

IMs could be used similarly, but for those computer programs (AOL, CompuServe, Yahoo Messenger, etc.--they might not have even been apps on phones then) they were IMs. On phones they became text messages or texts...maybe SMS or MMS, but not TMs.
